name: Quiet luxury, loud transformations
description: In The Dressmaker, Gertrude (Sarah Snook) transforms from 'dowdy' to elegant when she attends a dance in this dress. It's a popular cinema trope that shows how characters develop, but the 'makeover' trope isn't always a positive.

key_work.title: Gertrude Pratt's (Sarah Snook) silver dress from The Dressmaker
key_work.credit_line: Courtesy The National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
key_work.brief_description: The dress shows Tilly’s skill and sophistication, and the superiority of her designs in direct contrast to the bad wedding dress. Inspired by Dior, this dress elevates Gertrude’s figure.

end.title: Succession
end.creator_credit: Gary Sanchez Productions and Hyperobject Industries
end.brief_description: The lives of the Roy family as they contemplate their future once their aging father begins to step back from the media and entertainment conglomerate they control.

constellations_other.name: Quiet luxury, loud transformations
constellations_other.description: In The Dressmaker, Gertrude (Sarah Snook) transforms from 'dowdy' to elegant when she attends a dance in this dress. It's a popular cinema trope that shows how characters develop, but the 'makeover' trope isn't always a positive.

constellations_other.name: The forest for the trees
constellations_other.description: Marshmallow Laser Feast's Sanctuary of the Unseen Forest celebrates the majestic Colombian kapok tree. Let's look back at some of screen culture's other mighty trees and forests.

constellations_other.name: The spectre of the Romanovs
constellations_other.description: The Romanov dynasty has become a symbol of opulence throughout popular culture. Their final costume ball is even referenced in the coronation mood boards for Tony McNamara's The Great. Let's look at their history on-screen.

links.description: Gertrude Pratt (Sarah Snook) transforms from a wallflower into an empowered, glamorous woman through costuming in The Dressmaker. Yet her newfound elegance also gives her a sharp-witted arrogance, something Snook’s character Shiv Roy embodies in Succession.

end.title: The Talented Mr. Ripley [DVD]
end.creator_credit: Anthony Minghella, Tom Sternberg, William Horberg, Miramax Films and Paramount Pictures
end.brief_description: Based on the novel by Patricia Highsmith, The Talented Mr. Ripley is a story about a charismatic sociopath who would rather be a ‘fake somebody than a real nobody’.

constellations_other.name: Quiet luxury, loud transformations
constellations_other.description: In The Dressmaker, Gertrude (Sarah Snook) transforms from 'dowdy' to elegant when she attends a dance in this dress. It's a popular cinema trope that shows how characters develop, but the 'makeover' trope isn't always a positive.

links.description: Shiv Roy’s costuming in Succession is bold but understated. She exudes power through simplicity and fine lines, helping spark the ‘quiet luxury’ trend, which has been exemplified by celebrities like Gwyneth Paltrow. On-screen, Paltrow epitomised the trend in The Talented Mr. Ripley.

start.title: The Talented Mr. Ripley [DVD]

end.title: Titanic
end.creator_credit: James Cameron, Deborah Lynn Scott, Jon Landau, 20th Century Fox, Lightstorm Entertainment, Paramount, Peter Lamont and John Bruno
end.brief_description: 101-year-old Rose DeWitt Bukater tells the story of her life aboard the Titanic, 84 years later. A young Rose boards the ship with her mother and fiancé. Meanwhile, Jack Dawson and Fabrizio De Rossi win third-class tickets aboard the ship. Rose tells the whole story from Titanic’s departure through to its death—on its first and last voyage—on April 15, 1912.

constellations_other.name: Faking history
constellations_other.description: The Great takes a creative approach to its historical characters and settings that is mirrored in its costumes - this war dress might have a classic silhouette, but the grimy pearlescent fabric and striking oxblood detailing is completely modern. Faking history is a time-honoured tradition in film, from historical fiction to propaganda.

constellations_other.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_other.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

constellations_other.name: From queer period romances to surrealistic worlds
constellations_other.description: Explore the interconnections between queer period dramas, through to sci-fi and surrealistic worlds.

links.description: Costumes are important to characters in The Talented Mr Ripley. Conman Tom Ripley (Matt Damon) has to dress the part to infiltrate high society. Clothes are often a sign of class in movies, including Titanic, where Jack (Leonardo Dicaprio) has to navigate the prejudices of high society.

end.title: She's All That
end.creator_credit: Robert Iscove, Jennifer Gibgot, Denise Wingate, Casey O. Rohrs, Peter Abrams, Richard N. Gladstein, Robert L. Levy, FilmColony, Miramax, Tapestry Films, Charles William Breen and R. Lee Fleming Jr.
end.brief_description: A high schooler tries to revive his fading reputation, by agreeing to a seemingly impossible challenge - turn outcast Laney Boggs into a prom queen.

constellations_other.name: Quiet luxury, loud transformations
constellations_other.description: In The Dressmaker, Gertrude (Sarah Snook) transforms from 'dowdy' to elegant when she attends a dance in this dress. It's a popular cinema trope that shows how characters develop, but the 'makeover' trope isn't always a positive.

links.description: One of Titanic’s most iconic scenes sees Jack transform into a viable suitor via a dinner suit. This kind of transformation is a common trope, from The Dressmaker to teen films like She’s All That, when a ‘geeky’ teen is given a glamorous makeover.

start.title: She's All That
start.creator_credit: Robert Iscove, Jennifer Gibgot, Denise Wingate, Casey O. Rohrs, Peter Abrams, Richard N. Gladstein, Robert L. Levy, FilmColony, Miramax, Tapestry Films, Charles William Breen and R. Lee Fleming Jr.

end.title: Cruel Intentions
end.creator_credit: Denise Wingate and Neal H. Moritz

video_links.name: CRUEL INTENTIONS - Official Trailer - Back in Theaters for the 20th Anniversary

end.brief_description: Slaking a thirst for dangerous games, Kathryn challenges her stepbrother, Sebastian, to deflower their headmaster’s daughter before the summer ends. If he succeeds, the prize is the chance to bed Kathryn. But if he loses, Kathryn will claim his most prized possession.

constellations_other.name: Quiet luxury, loud transformations
constellations_other.description: In The Dressmaker, Gertrude (Sarah Snook) transforms from 'dowdy' to elegant when she attends a dance in this dress. It's a popular cinema trope that shows how characters develop, but the 'makeover' trope isn't always a positive.

constellations_other.name: Power and privilege, monarchy and make-up
constellations_other.description: The upper echelons of society explored through colour, make-up and scandal.

links.description: Another element of the ‘transformation’ plot often involves a bet. Cruel Intention, also released in 1999, had this premise when two upper-class siblings transform a ‘nerdy’ girl.

start.title: Cruel Intentions
start.creator_credit: Denise Wingate and Neal H. Moritz

end.title: Not Another Teen Movie
end.creator_credit: Joel Gallen, Buddy Johnson, Mike Bender, Phil Beauman, Florence-Isabelle Megginson, Steve Welch, Neal H. Moritz, Columbia Pictures, Neal H. Moritz Productions, Original Film, Joseph T. Garrity, Adam Jay Epstein and Andrew Jacobson
end.brief_description: On a bet, a gridiron hero at John Hughes High School sets out to turn a bespectacled plain Jane into a beautiful and popular prom queen in this outrageous send-up of the teen movies of the 1980s and ‘90s.

constellations_other.name: Quiet luxury, loud transformations
constellations_other.description: In The Dressmaker, Gertrude (Sarah Snook) transforms from 'dowdy' to elegant when she attends a dance in this dress. It's a popular cinema trope that shows how characters develop, but the 'makeover' trope isn't always a positive.

links.description: The bet/transformation trope is so prevalent, particularly in teen movies, that both She’s All That and Cruel Intentions are spoofed in this parody film.

start.title: Not Another Teen Movie
start.creator_credit: Joel Gallen, Buddy Johnson, Mike Bender, Phil Beauman, Florence-Isabelle Megginson, Steve Welch, Neal H. Moritz, Columbia Pictures, Neal H. Moritz Productions, Original Film, Joseph T. Garrity, Adam Jay Epstein and Andrew Jacobson
start.brief_description: On a bet, a gridiron hero at John Hughes High School sets out to turn a bespectacled plain Jane into a beautiful and popular prom queen in this outrageous send-up of the teen movies of the 1980s and ‘90s.

constellations_other.name: Quiet luxury, loud transformations
constellations_other.description: In The Dressmaker, Gertrude (Sarah Snook) transforms from 'dowdy' to elegant when she attends a dance in this dress. It's a popular cinema trope that shows how characters develop, but the 'makeover' trope isn't always a positive.

end.title: The Breakfast club
end.creator_credit: John Hughes, Ned Tanen and Universal Pictures
end.brief_description: John Hughes wrote and directed this film which was to become the quintessential high school drama of the 80s. Claire, the princess; Andrew, the jock; John, the criminal; Brian, the nerdy brain; and Alison, the basket case are all faced with spending nine hours together in Saturday detention. They begin the day as strangers having nothing in common, but as the day progresses, they slowly develop a bond in recognising that they are not as different as their places in the high school caste system would have them believe. Cast includes: Emilio Estevez, Judd Nelson, Molly Ringwald, Anthony Michael Hall, Ally Sheedy and Paul Gleason.

constellations_other.name: Quiet luxury, loud transformations
constellations_other.description: In The Dressmaker, Gertrude (Sarah Snook) transforms from 'dowdy' to elegant when she attends a dance in this dress. It's a popular cinema trope that shows how characters develop, but the 'makeover' trope isn't always a positive.

links.description: Perhaps the most influential teen movie is The Breakfast Club, which features a ‘makeover’ scene, where Claire (Molly Ringwald) transforms Alison (Ally Sheedy) from a goth to a popular girl. The trope is criticised for projected an idealised beauty standard.
